reviewText:
Let me start with stating that I'm a veteran PES player since SNES, entered some competition and won. So I've been playing this series since the beginning. Now, I don't know who quality-controls this game in KONAMI, but after 20 years, this game still repeating the same flaw over and over again.

Let me start with the PROs:

1. Good gameplay, improved animation and realism.

2. Very nice Master League, probably the best in the series.

The CONs:

1. Let me start with the interface.
a. Very ♥♥♥♥ interface design. They couldn't do it right with sophisticated design in the PS3 series (forgot which years), now they ruin it with ugly minimalistic design. They should learn from Google or other app designer who design minimalistic design with beauty. Champions League license saved them because some scoreboard has been improved since they licensed and copied its design.
b. The interface itself is troublesome and not made easy to navigate. You need to press so many button to quit the game. You need to follow so many step to go into command list in training mode. Then to resume the game, you can't just press start, but have to press B (or O) that many steps. And I don't know why the interface is very laggy, at best very low framerate like it's lagging. Note that I have GTX 970 and play the game itself smoothly.

2. The replay. OMG who approved this kind of replay? It is recorded like some baby holds the camera.
a. The height/ vertical angle is bad. I suspect this is because KONAMI wants to show off that they made a very nice grass and balls and stadium. Surprise, who cares? Well I do care about them but they are only ambiance, not the focus itself. The game should be the focus not the grass or the balls. KONAMI is repeating the same mistake like PES 2011 or something that showed kickoff with a very low angle because they wanted to show off the stadium they made. If you can get past the humiliation of playing on a poor PS3 port in 2015 after paying full price; you'll actually enjoy the experience but even the most hardened Pro Evo veterans will find this joke hard to take. EA Sports did the same on PC with FIFA 14 by releasing an old gen port but at least they were honest about the situation months beforehand. The fact this is full price is just insulting and that the squads haven't even been updated on many teams from the current transfer window suggests you're better off obtaining a refund and just going back to Pro Evolution Soccer 2015 instead. reviewText:
As a big fan of the series, I would really, really like to recommend this game but in its current state I just can't. While there are many promising gameplay elements, this game is plagued by a number of crippling issues:

1)updates and Konami's take on communication with the fanbase

Updates take way too long and the patch notes are as useful for understanding the effect of upates on overall gameplay as a bicycle is for scuba diving: 'We will also be doing minor updates to improve a lot of gameplay aspects that our players have been requesting(...).' Are you feeling as enlightened as I am, now?!

Offline line-up-updates will take until October 29th to be implemented, that is almost six weeks after release. Players have alerted Konami to a number of gameplay issues starting Day 1 and so far all the player base knows for sure is that Konami is working on an update.
What specific gameplay issues they are going to address with this update is anyone's guess, however. The aforementioned global roster update is the only new content us humble users are allowed to know about in advance.
Right now I can't help but wonder if Konami has not outsourced their PR for the game to the Public Security Intelligence Agency.

2)the sorry state of rosters and the terrible implementation of the UEFA-tournaments:

For the largest part, this game uses outdated team information. A recent patch dating October 1st updated only the online modes, but left the officialy licensed UEFA-Tournaments untouched, along with all other offline-modes.

For reasons beyond my limited mortal understanding Konami deceided to leave a couple of teams entirely out of the tournaments, such as Borussia Dortmund without even replacing them with a non-licensed counterpart.
Even worse, although Bayern Munich is a fully licensed team in exhibition mode, they are not available for the Champions League, so I am not about to excuse their abscence wth the limited licenses Konami aqquired.
Being a soccer enthusiast from Germany these two things immediately caught my attention and I know for a fact that the same holds true for a number of teams from other nations as well.

TL;DR: Don't get your hopes up for the UEFA-licensed modes and don't expect up-to-date rosters either.

3)Online gaming

Just like most of the other users I have experienced severe lag in online matches, alongside a grueling percentage of disconnects. I have in fact only been able to complete 2(!) out of 7 matches so far. That is just unacceptable for me and even in those 2 cases where I was able to finish the match crippling lags made the game seem about as enjoyable as undergoing a root canal treatment.
The frequent lags reduce what could have been a promising soccer game to a game of chance.

4)Goalkeepers and, to a lesser degree, defensive AI in general

The goalkeepers in this game are terrible, their catching skills are practically non-existant and in 1vs1-situations you basically have to aim directly at them in order for them to save. Diagonal shots like the ones Robben loves to fire from the corner of the box come with a success rate of what feels like 90 percent.

Through balls, especially lobbed ones, are way too effective against enemy defenders and goalkeepers alike. While defenders will react too slowly to the situation, goalkeepers will remain glued to their goal line. If your opponent has fast forward players you are in for a world of hurt and easily prevented goals.

5)the man in black

The Referee does not really exist. He is just there for offsides, throw-ins, corner and goal kicks. Gattuso could surely be persuaded to return to the field immediately if real life referees behaved like they do in this game. I have spent an entire 20min game trying to provoke a red card and failed miserably.

I did not even earn a booking. Sliding tackle from behind against a player who is not even remotely close to the ball? Just play on, the referee says. Maybe there is a cheat code implemented into the game that would allow you to call down a tactical nuke on the goalkeeper so that you could earn a red card, but short of that I cannot think of a way to incur the referee's wrath in any meaningful way.

6)In defence of the game

The aforementioned issues aside, Pro Evolution Soccer 2016 can be a fun game, as long as you stick to playing offline modes. The passing and the ball physics are nothing short of astonishing, the skill shots you can produce will make you feel like the next Messi and the fight for possession is thrilling and unpredictable. At its core, the game is a terific simulation and has lots of potential. Given these strenghts it is all the more baffling why the game is in the sorry state it is in right now.

Final verdict:

I have a feeling that with a little fine tuning most of these issues could have been resolved within a couple of weeks with some good, old-fashioned quality testing before release.

Konami should understand that customers and product testers are not identical target audiences. Yet with the game in its current state I cannot help but feel that by buying this game I have given my express permission to do their beta-testing for them and that is why I ultimately cannot give this game a thumbs up and recommend it to other players.

If they were to fix these issues in a timely and satisfactory manner I might be inclined to write a more favorable review in the future and put more emphasis on the undisputed strenghts of the game, but right now I absolutely do not feel like doing that.

Right now, I am deeply dissappointed that Pro Evolution Soccer 2016 does not nearly realize its full potential.

I have been playing football games since the Atari years (yeah, more like a ping-pong back then but still) and after PES peaked with PES 6 and started to nosedive, I switched to FIFA 10 and never looked back - until now.

After the mediocre FIFA 14 and the disappointing FIFA 15 I decided to switch back and check how things were going in PES-land. Oh-boy was I for a surprise!

I honestly have mixed feelings about this year's PES. I think most of it comes from the fact that the FIFA series is extremely polished and functional. For exemple, I found the general settings and menus of PES very cumbersome, not logical and overall... ugly.

The game itself is a let down, graphics and sound wise. Where in FIFA you have a thorough commentary with lots of insights and little bits of facts here and there, in PES everything is a bit bland and lifeless. The graphics are okey-ish (DX9 is very evident, specially lighting and shadows) with nice animations and I like the color palette, looking more natural to me than FIFA in my opinion.

Another downside is what plagued PES since its inception: the lack of licenses. I know it's not Konami's fault since EA has an almost total monopoly on it but still it leaves a sour taste when playing with generic teams and players.

What I do like though, is the tempo. The game feels more slowly paced compared to the steroid-infused FIFA and although the through-passes are a bit overpowered, the game is very nice and plays in a very interesting manner. I believe much of it will change with patches though.

Online is a joke and I couldn't finish one single match without being disconnected so I don't know how to evaluate it.

Anyway, I think I'll pass this year's PES and go back to FIFA. I will try to come back a couple of patches later and see how the game is going but for now, I don't recommend.

- PES 2008 (played it for some years until for some unknown reason the master league mode didn't work anymore) and
- FIFA 2012 (which I played from time to time until lately).
- Furthermore I can compare to the FIFA 2016 demo. (All PC versions.)

I had only 2 hours of playtime for this review, since I'm still not sure whether I will refund or not...

Pro:
- Some really great gameplay improvements (esp. ball moves)
- Better animations to some point (tackles)
- More realistic due to balls bouncing off foot etc.
- Difficulty level system is better balanced than with FIFA, where I win every game 10-0 on first 2 levels, but then again hardly ever score a goal on the next levels.

Undecided:
- Gameplay overall. Maybe I would have to get used to the animations and input reaction, but it feels a little to indirect.

Cons:
- Graphics: Not better than FIFA12 imho. Faces dull, grey, liveless.
- Audience/stadium looks crappy when it rains, due to almost everyone wearing grey rain capes...
- Some animations look strange (e.g. jumping opponents when playing a header or goalkeeper catching ball), because shadows on the ground look wrong -> you cannot really see in what direction (up/left/right/whatever/at all) the move goes
- Changing player running direction feels clumsy/slow/indirect
- Online: I get a lot of lagging. Finding a quick online game opponent took me about 5 minutes waiting time
- AI defense: COM players on my team just stand around and don't move at all with ball right next to them very often.
- still last seasons rosters... may be updated later, but the game is out now, so this does not leave a good impression on me


Conclusion:
Considering the above contras plus the fact that there are no licenses for most leagues, I find the price (50€) way too high, so I tend to refunding ( I'll give it a day of thinking...). Hard decision at this moment.
FIFA 2016 demo felt somehow to be the better package when it comes to the overall mix of graphics (if you need it) and gameplay.

reviewText:
Given all the trailers and hype in the months leading up to the release, you could be forgiven if you thought that this is finally the year for PES to usurp FIFA for the crown of football games on PC. Konami missed a clear 1-on-1 situation and it was not even close.


There are merits to this game; I think it is the best PES game on PC since PES 6. The monthly stats reports in Master League and the added features of fluid formations and tactics are reminiscent of Football Manager and do add some level of authenticity to the game.
The on-the-ball player movement, the timing for passes and tackles, manual aiming and the actual dynamics of the ball in different situations are much improved compared to previous incarnations of the series, and arguably, better than that of FIFA 16. As such the gameplay of PES 2016 is also more challenging and tactical than FIFA 16 (by comparison of Superstar and Legendary).


But there are a number of glaring problems that undermine most of what is good about the game. The most prominent problem is the UI, which is an eye-sore, but the graphics are equally appaling. The fact that the PC graphics isn't anywhere close to what had been shown in previews is deceptive and incredibly offensive from Konami.
Online play is plagued with lag, long waiting time and poor eventual matchmaking.
The previous addition of MyClub serves no purpose other than as a rival FUT, it lacks originality; they have made some changes this year but the connection to their server is too unstable, the mechanics and gameplay depth are also lagging behind that of FUT.
Roster updates are not being done promptly enough and offline capability is lacking, which is a big negative when things in this genre is about authenticity.
Some aspects of the actual football game are short of what is expected, in particular, the leniency of referees to some outrageous tackles, the inability for GK to catch or deal with set pieces, the over-aggressive defensive plays and the frequent, significant fluctuation of player form in the space of days.
Team kits, team names, team crests, player names, league names...it’s one thing to have UCL and UEL license, but not having the others really affected the game’s authenticity. You can argue that EA lacked certain licensing as well, but at least they have worked hard to present appealing substitutes to the gamers and have also worked in other areas to compensate for their inadequacies. I cannot say the same for the case of Konami and PES.


PES 2016 is still a quintessential PES game, good mostly in terms of player-tactics and on-the-ball dynamics. If you are a PES-exclusive player, this is certainly an improvement from last year’s game. If you are a FIFA-exclusive player wondering what the PES hype was about, the answer is ‘nothing noteworthy’. If you are still undecided or are a newbie to the football game sub-genre, I would wholeheartedly recommend against buying PES 2016.


tl;dr: FIFA is still King of the football games for PC.

reviewText:
I love PES, but up to a point.

PES 16 isn't a new game, it should have been but it isn't. It feels like a stand alone patch for 15 because all Konami have done is simply remove some of the good parts of 15 and add some of the missing things from 15 and voila you have PES 16!

Examples:

Good parts taken out of 15...

1). The shooting, which was good in 15, they've messed up in 16, so now whether you lightly touch the shoot button or hold it down there isnt going to be any difference (so the powerbar is pretty much useless), in 15 you had to hold down the shoot and pre-emptively make the space which was fun imo and added a little more skill to shot creation. Now the ball is simply a balloon with no weight at all to it.

2). The animations, in 15 I had no problem, players felt like they had weight and the collision system worked well and the animations fitted the movements the players made. But in 16 they've sped everything inadvertently by adding extra animations so when you line up a few tricks consecutively there isn't enough time for this to be realistically portrayed so the animations skip and you end up with it looking a little jittery and skittish.

3). Passing, having tried all passing modes (passing assistance) in 16 it would seem that there doesnt seem to be any consistency between them for I notice certain passes (quite easy passes at that) simply won't go to the person you're aiming for so in effect these options are missing, whereas in 15 I could eliminate that problem by changing (lowering) pass asisstance.

Added the things that were missing from 15...

1). Cursor change, whereas in 15 it was quite sluggish, in 16 it is much more responsive and all the better

2). Player response time, compared to 15 the players in 16 respond much faster to loose balls which is good, although as mentioned above because of the animation skips and inconsistent player motions things can get a little like sensible soccer (defenders getting sucked behind attackers in an instant and almost comedic manner).

3). Ball in the air options, greatly improved from 15, I've already managed 3 overhead kicks and many volleys, things that were missing in 15 - you basically had little control over what happened in the air in 15 in terms of attacking options whereas now if you want to volley simply wait for the ball to drop lower than chest height if you want an overhead kick position yourself under the ball with your back to goal - definately much better.

Overall, if I am honest I have to say 15 is better. I prefer the meatier shots and the heavier weight to the players. However, I am a person who likes a bit more realism over arcade action and I think 15 felt a bit more like a simulator so it gets my vote.

How to score this game?

Well, considering that it (PES 16) offers nothing new in terms of graphics, interface and sound (sorry but I detest Peter Drury what's worse is in PES 16 he sounds like Ned Boulting (another soulless ITV drone) who I also destest, and doesn't actually build on anything good from 15 (because they've simply taken them away or changed them for the worse) means that this game feels like a patch. In fact the more I think about it the more it could be for at the beginning of PES 15's release Konami stated that they wouldn't be creating any further patches that would alter the gameplay of 15, where they basically saving that for 16? Also, everything else seems to fit - the team changes are the exact same team roster for Arsenal is the exact same as 15, even Diaby is still there! I was wondering why the updates just suddenly stopped way last year, ok I can understand the gameplay not being touched (which is ok I like the gameplay in 15 as it is) but what happend to Data packs? There were none!

So the more I think about it the more it makes sense. Konami is in crisis, so what's the cheap option? Simply stop putting money into the creation of patches for the current (15) game and use those resources instead to create a patch (I was going to say 'larger patch' but it's not, for I wouldn't have minded paying the money as long as the team were actually up-to-date but sadly they're not) that they can essentially call a new game because blatantly that's what it is, a gameplay patch nothing more and as we approach the release of the new game don't bother releasing a demo for the PC that could potentially reflect any of this. It all makes sense.

So I've paid for a poor patch that if I had downloaded from PESEdit.com I would have deleted - the shocking thing is with PESedit at least you get the real team kits and rosters on top of the gameplay changes with this effort from Konami you get none of that! It just goes to show how much I have been ripped off.

So onto the verdict

Considering the above

2/10

However, if PES 15 had never existed then...

6.5/10


P.S. Like some other users I will be using the refund option

reviewText:
Even if you ignore the fact that the PC version of the game is a poor port of the PS3 version it's hard to recommend PES2016.

Gameplay wise this is an improvement on 2015 and the user interface, which has never been up to much, is also much better then in previous versions.

As someone who does not play online the Master League is the game mode I use most. And although it has been refined since 2015 a lot of the same issues remain, particularly around the AI. In significant games (cup semi-finals, league winning fixtures etc.) the AI ups the difficulty by essentially cheating. Players become untackleable, your AI controlled team mates do stupid things (e.g. stepping aside from 50/50s, making rash tackles) and your commands become more like suggestions. Even when the game isn't actively trolling you there are issues. Opposition players can take the ball from you from just about any angle with minimal contact regardless of the relative strength of the players in question. Stats like pace seem to be completely irrelevant at times as an exhausted, lumbering central defender will easily catch up to your fresh, speedy attacker. Through balls in general are just a hot mess - unless you are using fully manual controls it is a complete lottery as to what will happen when you play one.

PES2016 has a huge amount of promise but is hampered by poor visuals and a terrible, and at times rage-inducing, Master League AI. If you can get it in the sale then it's probably worth it, but for full price it's hard to recommend it.

reviewText:
This is a game I wanted to enjoy, I really did, but after 50 or so hours of play, this game has finally sapped all levels of enthusiasm and enjoyment from me, and I can no longer tolerate it's many, many flaws. It's problems are symptomatic of not just a series, but a genre that has become stagnant and lacks any real innovation. And therein lies one of the main issues with sport simulations; the games are restricted by the real world elements. As a fond, even dare I say, hardcore fan of the Pro Evolution Soccer series in it's Playstation2 heyday, it's lack of meaningful progress in the last ten years is saddeningly glaring. Whilst games in nearly every genre have evolved tenfold in the last decade, football games, including all of the big hitters, PES, FIFA and FM, have done very, very little, and in a genre where annual releases are the standard, this is extremely poor.

I'll talk about a few things I feel this game has done right before focusing on the negative. In terms of core mechanics and gameplay, the passing is very solid, for the most part and there are a lot of unique passing animations that add an organic feel to passing, the passing feels weighty and satisfying.
The ease of implementing custom tactical settings is excellent, and this has always been something PES has done better than FIFA; it's drag and drop system of creating formations feels fluid and offers some room for creative formations and strategies. The game also lets you switch between other custom systems on the fly during the game, again offering space for creativity.

Then there's Master League. It has the remarkable quality of instigating feelings of nostalgia whilst remaining hopelessly archaic and frustrating. It has more or less remained untouched from the series glory days and it's idiosyncrasies now feel out of touch and counter intuitive to maintaining a notion of simulation. It still features the haphazard 'coloured arrow' system of player condition, the same system that has been in the series since it was called 'International Superstar Soccer', some 20 years ago. It's a system that feels so arbitrary and unfair, that it breaks any semblance of simulation, and whilst it might have been acceptable 10 or so years ago, there is no room for this anymore. Add to this, the equally bizarre in modern context, international game schedule, which sees half of your players leave for international duty at random points during the season to come back completely fatigued and effectively unselectable for the next 3 or more games. There is no excuse for this anymore.

The gameplay itself has fared little better. Goalkeepers are comically inept to the point of being game breaking, failing to make even the simplest of saves, parrying the tamest of shots and positioning themselves with such epic ineptitude that it's hard to believe they are seemingly made to represent real, professional athletes. Their absolute stubborn refusal to move off their goal lines will gift you many undeserved, easy goals. Without the explicit intention of hyperbole, I would argue that these are probably the worst goalkeepers I have had the misfortune of seeing in a video game.

The controls and players themselves feel sluggish and very unresponsive, especially when defending. Trying to switch defenders can be beyond a nightmare at times, with the game often straight refusing to switch to a relevant player, or even worse, upon gaining control of a player, all of their momentum and movement completely dissipates as though the very life of them is being instantly drained. First touches feel heavy even when purposefully trapping the ball. A lot of the time, it seems as though your touch goes in a random direction rather than the actual direction you are holding on the controller. The same goes with passing at times, almost to the point where it feels that the game is just passing wherever the hell it feels like.

And then there is the scripting, momentum or whatever other term you have for it. It is so rudimentary and blunt that it becomes completely insulting to the player. Segments of paly feel painfully contrived, and on the higher difficulties, it results in feeling completely powerless to the whim of the game. There are times you can literally feel that the computer opponents are going to score in the next piece of play, and more often then not, my fears were confirmed with a rippling net. It creates this overbearing feeling of unfairness for the sake of cheap drama, and the unsubtlety of it all is completely immersion breaking.

I haven't tried much of the online play, because the game performs so poorly in online games and there seems to be a lot of lag, regardless of your connection quality. There is also a lot of rampant cheating in the online scene, but I suppose I can't fault the game itself for that, although it has been suggested that Konami ought to do more to prevent this.

Overall, despite the game having it's moments, it feels too old, too slow and offers little to nothing new, despite the decades of ongoing development. I seem to only be able to play this game for an hour or so at a time these days before I ground down by the vast flaws of this title. This might be a game that others can still enjoy, but I feel laboured playing this game, and it usually ends with putting me in a sour mood. I cannot recommend this game.

reviewText:
Let's start with the more obvious flaws of the game. One, lack of official licensing that has plagued the series since the beginning of time. It's still continuing until now giving the game less credence than the FIFA series. Second, the visual aspect of the game pales in comparison with the FIFA series. The crowd looks ugly, the goal celebration lacks polish, and it lacks the HD texture of the game console cousin.

But that doesn't matter right? What matters is the gameplay? Well, here's where it gets ugly. The passing system is hit or miss. Sometimes you can thread through a quick pass to your players between enemy defense, other time your players would pass half-heartedly and the ball would go to your passing target at crawl speed which is easily intercepted by the enemy defense. And the AI defense is insane! Sometimes they are able to predict when you pass the ball leading to them able to intercept more than 10 times in a 10 minutes match.

EDIT 15/04/2016: And your AI teammate movement leaves a lot to be desired. They don't find spaces and intentionally positioned themselves close to enemy defender even when attacking. This positioning causes our passes to be easily intercepted by enemy defender when we pass the ball, when we control the received pass, and when we start dribbling the ball. I had seen this happened so many time that this must be intentional programming by Konami. This doesn't make any sense whatsoever.

EDIT 19/05/2016: ♥♥♥♥ you for using scripted AI. It's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that players who have low body balance able to push my 90 and 95 rated body balance defender. Some of the AI passing is near ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t with pin point accuracy for a low level team. Dont ♥♥♥♥ing put this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t on me. It isn't fair, it's ♥♥♥♥ing putting the player into massive disadvantage where we can't pass nor can we intercept any of the opposing team passes.

All of this is pretty disheartening since the game itself is very rewarding for players who rely on passes and tactical play instead of the run and gun of FIFA series. Since the passing works mysteriously you'll have to rely on luck whenever you try to pass (EVEN NORMAL SHORT PASS) the ball. This is sad because i've been a fan of the PES series since the console era. And can you believe this is the first time i was able to legitimately purchase the game on Steam? Last year i couldn't buy PES 2015 because i was region locked by the stupid Konami. Now i get back to the game and see the passing system botched, the visual fidelity is lacking, and the game roster is still as stupid as ever.

EDIT: And do you know how hard it is to make the AI off balance without resorting to violent tackle? Most of the time they are able to stay on their feet and thus able to regain the posession back. The higher difficulty would make it nigh impossible to tackle AI players just like in the old PES.

EDIT May 2016: This is nitpicking. But why can't i pick my match time in the Master League? I don't care about immersion. The game performance worsen during daytime match due to the shadow and brightness effect. But hey, i can't change match time since it's immersion breaking. It's more immersive breaking when the game lags so badly during the day than during the night.

What year is this? The Master League mode still has the same ♥♥♥♥ed up international call-up during the season. I can't set whether i could withdraw my players or not, and almost all of my players went back from international matchdays exhausted. Meanwhile, the opposing AI team suffer no set back and can play their original starting line-up while i must scrounnge bottom of the rosters for any meaningful players. It will take several matches until all of my roster are fit again. This is insane. This is literally the same fatigue problem harking all the way from PES 5.

reviewText:
I have mainly been playing the become a legend mode on the highest difficulty. My main issue with the game is that sometimes it feels like the game has decided on beforehand who'll win a match. The same issue was in PES 2015. I can be playing in FC Barcelona and be facing a low-level team with crappy stats (~70 or below on offense, midfield and defense), but the opposition plays like they're the best team in the world. They're not missing any passes, making perfectly timed tackles and scores on their chances. And their defence is Gods, no matter if it's a defence man or a forward. My player has 96 in speed, and sometimes I've faced players with like 75 in speed, but when a team mate plays a through ball the opposing player will get there first, no matter if he's behind me when the ball is played. Meanwhile my team cannot do anything right; they cannot take the ball from the opposition, they cannot make any decend pass, and they certainly wont be trying to hit the net. It means it's only up to me, as a single player in that team, to produce something offensively AND take responsibilities in the defence. And while struggling throughout the game, and maybe finally scoring a goal, you'll be sure that the opposition will make 2 goals pretty quick after that to get ahead, without really being challenged. It's pretty frustrating when those games happens. Especially if you've been through all the Champions league stages with an ease, and suddenly your team sucks and you're out of the competition.

Another really frustrating thing in BAL (I think people experience the same thing in Master League) is the injury bug. On the highest difficulty they'll make perfectly time sliding tackles (from Normal and upwards) and if you're hit you'll be injuried (most of the time). Sometimes your player stands up again after a while, but most of the times he'll be injured for weeks. This happens several times per season, making you miss a lot of games and if you're injuried you'll not be picked for the national team games, even though they'll be played after your injury has ended. It happens to your team mates as well, but not as frequent. It's worth to mention that my player has the max value on injury resistance, but that'll do nothing in this game it seems.

The last thing that bugs me is the goalkeepers. They just can't seem to save anything if the ball is hit close enough. The consequence is that you and the opposition will be scoring a lot of goals. 3-3, 4-3, 2-3, 4(+)-0, and so on is what most of the games will end. A few games is normal" games

This is a good incarnation of the PES series, and is as enjoyable as any of those I have played so far.

I began in the late 90s on the PS1 and found this superior to FIFA. Of course, FIFA became morelike PES, and PES seemed to lose its way - 2014 was nearly unplayable for me. The issues with textures and licences can be solved by searching for the Smoke patch.

The Master League and the like is the best I've seen, with enough arcadey management to make the team more detailed than before: roles are allocated automatically, and there is a real sense of the team growing.

I haven't played online as I spread my time across more than a few genres. I imagine that those who love that side of this game might be disappointed from what I've read. For the rest, playing with friends in RL is decent as it always has been.

So, for those willing to search and patch the game (all with .exe files once unzipped), this is a worthy return to the series for the past five years. Wolves FC marching up the 1st Division is vindication enough for me...

reviewText:
All in all a very good game of football, and I'd have to agree with most reviews in that this is the football game to buy this year (although I'd suggest getting the PS4 or Xbox One version if you have the choice). It might not have the meticulous authenticity of FIFA but PES 2016 is plainly just a much more enjoyable football game to play, and has actually shown consistent improvement year to year - and this year Konami have absolutely nailed the gameplay. Remember, the only way they'll be able to implement all the licenses in the future is if you actually buy the game, and it's definitely worth buying this year.

Pros:
-Fantastic gameplay - passing, tackling and shooting all feel natural and dynamic than in FIFA
-GP system
-Unpredictable matches
-Master League overhaul makes it a lot more fun to play; a much better interface, slightly better transfer negotiations (though still not on FIFA's level), in-depth stats
-UEFA Champions League, Europa League, Super Cup and Copa Libertadores licenses, and UEFA Euro 2016 is confirmed to be added at a later date
-Player controlled celebrations
-Commentary improved but still not great
-Although a blatant Ultimate Team clone, MyClub is very entertaining
-Dynamic weather
-Expansive edit suite as per usual
-Player models look very good

Cons:
-Although perfectly functional, the game plan menus could be a little easier on the eye; they often look clunky
-Licenses for Premier League teams (except Man United) still missing; option file support non-existent and PC is actually the most difficult platform to import images on
-Disappointing PC port in general, graphics are nowhere near up to the standard of PS4/Xbox One, no mouse support
-Some animations still look somewhat robotic
-Can be a tad too easy for experienced players, even on Super Star difficulty
-Texture quality of the crowd is sub-par

This is the first PES that i´ve bought after the 2011 version, after which I switched to FIFA. Before that I played almost every game of the series ( and enjoyed it ). This year I wanted to give it another try and I have to admit that I have some mixed feelings about it, though I recommend it, not to everyone but to people who prefere pure football over graphics and presentation.
Of course there are lots of negative aspects about the game and I have to admit that I don´t like them. The presentation, crowd, animations and graphics are far away from what could have been possible on this platform...again. Konami isn´t very interested in the pc community as it seems. But that is not new. I guess it´s a general problem of asian publishers who have their focus on consoles and handhelds. Nevertheless, this is, year after year, a punch to the face for all pc players.
However, if you can keep these facts out of your mind and don´t consider them most important for a football game, you will have a lot of fun with PES 2016. The gameplay is great, it feels like football ( especially when you´ve played football in real life, like myself ). The speed of the game is clearly slower than FIFA´s, although you can speed it up via gameplay settings if you like. In my opinion the slower gamespeed makes it more realistic, but everyone has his preferences. The tactical behaviour of the players and the changes you can make are great. There are lots of possibilities to create goal opportunities, teammates are moving into good positions, the defense feels strong ( when you compare it to FIFA ), which means that you have to create your chances instead of dribbling through the whole team. You can score in so many different ways instead of learning the positions or situations ( FIFA ) where you score every time.

What I want to say with all that is, that the gameplay ( for me ) clearly overweights the visual issues of the game ( which it obviously has).

Recommended, as I said earlier, to people who prefere pure football over graphics.

reviewText:
If you want to complain about the graphics and the fact that PES 2016 is an apparent port, then buy the game on console. Easy.

That aside, after playing for only a few hours it is easy to see the differences between this and PES 2015. Gameplay feels a lot more fluid, the animations have improved immensely, the new commentators' enthusiasm is great, and the A.I plays just as well.

There are also a lot of little upgrades such as the cutscenes that add to the immersion of the game. If you like football games, then give this one a play!

reviewText:
To start... seriously who cares how it looks? Have real PES players ever cared about that?

Gameplay is what matters and that has improved many times over PES 2015.

Getting more into details.

- It seems COM levels dropped a bit so Pro seems way too easy to beat and Top Player feels more like Pro in 2015.
- Online gameplay differs to the offline, which is normal but seems further apart than in 2015. What I mean , it is very hard to defent hence the high scores (played 5 games almost all of them had 5 goals in first half. I put it also down to the length of games, since 2015 10 min was way too long for realistic scores, 7 mins matches seem perfect for me.
- In 2016 I feel I can create almost any action I want, players make runs, fight for the ball, respond quickly to controls etc.
- some nice animations on first touches, unconventional passes done by better players - this gives some great feel to the game

Of course must admit current price is a bit of a rip off considering that PC gamers are not getting all features and graphic uplift, so for that reason I would still recommend the game but maybe wait for a price reduction.

reviewText:
Ok...

So, YES. THIS DOES NOT LOOK AS GOOD AS THE PS4/X1 VERSION. Not even close. It only looks a tiny bit better than the PS3/X360 release and visually speaking, is a current gen port. However, they warned us this would be the case since JUNE, saying that the PC version was a hybrid that was better than the current gen, but not as good as next gen (in terms of visuals). They said they didn't have all the resources to fully port the next gen version (probably ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, I admit.)

HOWEVER.

This is the best football game I have ever played in my life. I have played FIFA since FIFA 06, and this is the best football game I have ever played. The gameplay is really special, it flows very naturally, and while its not perfect, FIFA plays like a disgusting joke compared to this game.

And thats...about all it has going for it.

Master League is ehh
All the other modes are ehh, so ehh that I don't even remeber what they are.
And liscences (obviously) are non existant as usual for the BPL and the Bundesliga.


So if you can handle going back to the pile of garbage that is FIFA because the game isn't as pretty as you want it, don't buy this game. But if you can stomach some average visuals, you won't regret this game. Its really great in terms of what matters - The 90 minutes on the pitch.

P.S. it actually isn't a direct copy of the current gen version, It's its own hybrid version and contains several features that the current gen release doesnt, including extra custscenes and animations. Still, Konami sucks.
